1. A 12-year-old boy presents with progressive numbness and tingling in his feet and hands, accompanied by frequent painless injuries and slow wound healing. His parents report that he has been clumsy and frequently falls, with muscle weakness noted in his lower limbs. Physical examination reveals decreased deep tendon reflexes, absent pain and temperature sensation in a stocking-glove distribution, and foot deformities including high arches. Autonomic symptoms such as lack of sweating and occasional episodes of orthostatic dizziness have also been observed. There is a family history of similar symptoms in a maternal uncle. Nerve conduction studies indicate absent sensory nerve action potentials consistent with sensory neuronopathy. Genetic testing confirms a mutation in the SPTLC1 gene, supporting a diagnosis of Hereditary Sensory and Autonomic Neuropathy Type Ia. Management focuses on symptomatic treatment and prevention of injuries.

output:
THINKING: The doctor is asking broadly why I came today, so I should mention my main feelings and concerns, even if I don't have all the words. I want to explain my symptoms honestly, maybe how they’re bothering me or scaring me a little. I should keep it simple and real, not overthink.

ANSWER: I'm a 12-year-old boy. Lately, my hands and feet feel really numb and tingly, and I keep getting hurt even though I don’t notice right away. I fall a lot and feel kind of weak in my legs, and I guess I just wanted to see what’s going on with me.
